title: New Jersey Weighs $1.5 Billion in Credit Bets Managed by Goldman Sachs; The state pension system is considering an increase in private credit investments through two separately managed accounts
text:
Both commitments would "accelerate exposure to the private-credit asset class" for the pension system and ease a restructuring of its private-credit holdings, according to Jared Speicher, the division's head of private equity and private credit.

The system is currently trailing its allocation targets for the strategy, according to a memo about the proposed investments by Shoaib Khan, the division's acting director and chief investment officer. He said that a commitment to syndicated loans could be fully deployed within two months rather than the 18 to 36 months it would take to fully invest money placed in a more traditional drawdown fund.

Mr. Speicher told pension trustees that the separately managed account for syndicated loans would provide "a risk-return profile consistent with private-credit but with liquidity measured in weeks rather than quarters or years."

The proposed $1 billion commitment for the syndicated-loan strategy, which targets investments in below-investment-grade senior secured or first-lien loans, would follow the division's $1 billion pledge in July to PGIM Inc., a Prudential Financial Inc. company, for a similar syndicated-loan strategy, according to Mr. Speicher.

The division would muster the capital for the syndicated loan account with the Goldman asset management arm by drawing it from lower-yielding investments in cash equivalents and treasuries, where the pension is currently overweight, Mr. Khan indicated in the memo. The documents say that assuming the $1 billion is fully invested through the proposed account, the estimated annualized yield improvement would surpass $40 million compared with cash and government bonds.

The separately managed account would invest in floating-rate debt and target 6% returns, with leverage levels of as much as 75% of loan values, Mr. Speicher said.

"Practically everything is [a] floating rate, so there is no duration risk," with rising inflation and interest rates, Bill Connors, the division's head of income, said at the meeting.

More than half of the $500 million separately managed private-credit account would target first-lien debt of sponsor-led midmarket companies, Mr. Connors said. Another 30% would be used to pursue an opportunistic strategy managed by Goldman's hybrid capital division and the rest would focus on mezzanine, senior credit or specialty lending strategies.

Taken together, the vehicle's blended net leverage returns would be targeted at 11% to 13%, Mr. Connors said. The account would start out with 30 to 40 existing loans made with Goldman's balance-sheet capital, so as much as half the committed funds could be invested at closing, he said.
